narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The main takeaway: Reproduction affects EVERYONE, regardless of gender and/or desire to have children, sometimes in sneaky ways one wouldn't be aware of without engaging with them critically in a course like this. I learned about all the ways reproduction is monitored, medicalized and affected by societal assumptions, from obvious ways like birth control to less intuitive things like access to assisted reproduction technologies. We also discussed the history of some of these practices, and the way different people have been excluded from progress in reproductive rights, or even ways reproduction has been weaponized to exacerbate the oppression of certain people.
I learned a lot about sociological ways of looking at reproduction and knowledge-making.
I learned the politics surrounding reproduction, contraception, abortion, and other modes of having children.
This course provided me with a deep understanding of the many facets of the politics of reproduction. The course did a wonderful job of spanning disciplines to give a multi-faceted view of the topic.

Through this course, I learned how to write succinct responses for the weekly readings as well as short sociological papers. I also learned about the connections between culture, science, individualism, policies, and large institutions and how they all play a role how we view reproduction.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The content and Professor Almeling's expertise are incredibly strong and engaging. Not so much a weakness, but the readings are ESSENTIAL to get something out of this class, and the length of the readings may be daunting for some people even if they are genuinely interested in the material.

I loved this class! It's all strengths Prof. Almeling is fantastic at facilitating discussion, the readings were almost all fantastic (and Prof. Almeling was extremely open to feedback on those readings so you're welcome, future seminar-takers), and the assignments were engaging and extremely reasonable. No weaknesses whatsoever.

No weaknesses! Although some readings could be shortened a tad

Strengths: The teaching was phenomenal. We created our own community in a zoom environment, and I think that is the biggest thing to be proud of. The class readings were interesting, discussions were engaging, and Professor Almeling was approachable and caring. I walked away a better person because of this class!

Strengths: Well-organized---sometimes seminars can devolve into really abstract discussions, but Professor Almeling was always focused on helping students understand the course's main questions. This was a really enlightening class, and the readings tied in perfectly to the discussion without relying too heavily on remote details from the text. 
Weaknesses: none that I can think of
This course was honestly great. Prof. Almeling facilitated a great discussion each class while simultaneously using her expertise to guide and add to the conversation. No weaknesses!

Strengths - thought-provoking discussions in class; readings; not many assignments
Weaknesses - none?

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Almeling was conscious of Zoom fatigue and made sure to place breaks into the almost-two-hour seminar. She was also very aware of everything happening outside the class (the pandemic, the election) and made adjustments to deadlines accordingly.
I loved group breakout rooms!
The virtual seminar format worked very well.

One practice that worked really well was cutting the class time by 20 minutes as well as giving us a 3 minute break in the middle of class. Learning (and participating) though Zoom is exhausting, so the shorter class time slightly helped with Zoom fatigue. Also, Professor Almeling was super accommodating with assignments and adjusting due dates in order to make all of our lives easier.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! As long as you're willing to do the reading, everyone should take this course. The main takeaway is that reproduction affects EVERYONE, and learning about it will make you thankful of this new perspective.

Absolutely!! This is such an amazing course, if you're interested in the subject material at all it's so worth taking if you get in. I'm still thinking (and will continue to think) about everything we discussed related to knowledge creation and the way it interacts with culture.
YES a hundred times yes. The course was spot on!
Absolutely---this is an approachable course for students from pretty much all academic backgrounds, and it was probably one of the best courses I've taken at Yale or elsewhere.
Yes. This is one of the best classes I have taken at Yale. I would highly recommend taking a class with Prof. Almeling.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student whos interested in the topic and would be excited to read sociological papers on how society views reproduction and associated topics.

100%. This was my favorite class at Yale in my 4 years, and I definitely recommend taking it if you get in. Not only is Professor Almeling well versed in the material and very excited to share her knowledge, she also remains dedicated to making sure students in her class take away information they can use for years to come.
